hook.text: Red. Blue. Yellow. Green. These are hues â€” the pure color name, stripped of lightness, darkness, or intensity. Hue is the simplest property of color.

buildup.text: Hue is a color's position on the color wheel. It's the family name: all blues â€” navy, sky, teal, baby blue â€” share the blue hue. Hue doesn't describe how light, dark, or vivid a color is.

discovery.text: There are infinite hues in the spectrum, but we name 12 on the standard color wheel. Between any two named hues, there's a continuous gradient of unnamed transitional hues.

twist.text: Brown isn't a hue â€” it's actually dark, desaturated orange. Pink isn't a separate hue either â€” it's light red. Many colors we name as separate are just variations of a base hue.

climax.text: Look at objects around you and name just their hue. Ignore how light or vivid they are. That wooden table? Orange hue. That sky? Blue hue. Simplify to the family.

punchline.text: Hue is the 'what color.' Saturation and value are the 'what kind.' Start with hue.
